The last few pages (from p. 71 onwards) contain several 
tables which have not hitherto been published, showing the 
characters of bacteria obtained by cultivation from the 
alimentary canal of oysters, mussels, cockles, whelks and 
periwinkles. As announced in B. A. Reports 1898 p. 560,
bacilli resembling the Colon bacillus of Man were frequently 
isolated, but nothing absolutely identical with the 
Typhoid bacillus was found.
These pages contain a further result which has not 
been published anywhere, - the identity of some <u>bacilli <\u>
from the alimentary canal of oysters etc., with the 
<u>B. enteridis sporogenes <\u> of Klein.
I am very strongly of opinion that the paper in its 
present form, consisting largely of a mere rescript of published 
work, should not be published by the Royal Society.
The two new points in it, namely the description of 
the <u>protractor pedis <\u> muscle, and the discovery of <u>Bacillus 
enteridis sporogenes <\u> in the alimentary canal of Molluscs,
do not seem to me of sufficient importance to justify publication 
by the Royal Society, even after removal of extraneous 
matter from the paper.
I am therefore of opinion that the Council should be 
advised not to publish the paper at all.
I am, Dear Mr. Chairman,
Yours very truly 
W.F.R. Weldon
